document.title: Commuting ordinary differential operators with polynomial coefficients and automorphisms of the first Weyl algebra

creator.personname: Andrey E. Mironov and Alexander B. Zheglov
creator.contact: The first author was supported by RSF (grant 14-11-00441).

abstract.name: Abstract
abstract.p: In this paper we study rank two commuting ordinary differential operators with polynomial coefficients and the orbit space of the automorphisms group of the first Weyl algebra on such operators. We prove that for arbitrary fixed spectral curve of genus one the space of orbits is infinite. Moreover, we prove in this case that for for any ≥n1 there is a pair of self-adjoint commuting ordinary differential operators of rank two =L4+(+∂x2⁢V(x))2⁢W(x), L6, where ⁢W(x),⁢V(x) are polynomials of degree n and +n2. We also prove that there are hyperelliptic spectral curves with the infinite spaces of orbits.

para.p: The group of automorphisms of the first Weyl algebra A1={∑=j0nuj(x)∂xj,uj∈C[x]} acts on the set of solutions of the equation

Math.text: formulae@(f * open-interval@(X, Y) = ((sum _ (list@(j, i) = 0)) ^ n)@(alpha _ (i * j) * X ^ i * Y ^ j) = 0, list@(X, Y) element-of A _ 1, alpha _ (i * j) element-of C)

para.p: i.e. if ∈X,YA1 satisfy (1) and ∈φ⁢Aut(A1), then ⁢φ(X),⁢φ(Y) also satisfy (1). The group ⁢Aut(A1) is generated by the following automorphisms

Math.text: formulae@(varphi _ 1 * x = alpha * x + beta * partial-differential _ x, formulae@(varphi _ 1 * partial-differential _ x = list@(gamma * x + delta * partial-differential _ x, alpha, beta, gamma), formulae@(delta element-of C, alpha * delta - beta * gamma = 1)))
formulae@(varphi _ 2 * x = x + P _ 1 * partial-differential _ x, varphi _ 2 * partial-differential _ x = partial-differential _ x)
formulae@(varphi _ 3 * x = x, varphi _ 2 * partial-differential _ x = partial-differential _ x + P _ 2 * x)

para.p: where P1,P2 are arbitrary polynomials (see [1]). So, ⁢Aut(A1) consists of tame automorphisms. A natural and important problem is to describe the orbit space of the group action of ⁢Aut(A1) in the set of solutions of (1). If one describes the orbit space it gives a chance to compare ⁢End(A1) and ⁢Aut(A1) (⁢End(A1) consists of endomorphisms :φ→A1A1, i.e. =[⁢φ(∂x),⁢φ(x)]1). Let us recall the Dixmier conjecture: =⁢End(A1)⁢Aut(A1), or in other words, if differential operators Ln,Lm with polynomial coefficients satisfy the string equation

Math.text: closed-interval@(L _ n, L _ m) = 1

para.p: then Lm,Ln can be obtained from x,∂x with the help of compositions φj above (the general Dixmier conjecture for An is stably equivalent to the Jacobian conjecture due to [2]). Berest has proposed the following interesting conjecture:

p.text: If the Riemann surface corresponding to the equation =f0 with generic ∈α⁢ijC has genus =g1 then the orbit space is infinite, and if >g1 then there are only finite number of orbits.

para.p: One can prove that if there are finite number of orbits for some equation (1) then =⁢End(A1)⁢Aut(A1).
In this paper we consider the equation

Math.text: formulae@(Y ^ 2 = list@(X ^ (2 * g + 1) + c _ (2 * g) * X ^ (2 * g) + dots + c _ 1 * X + c _ 0, X), formulae@(Y element-of A _ 1, c _ j element-of C))

para.p: Using Schur’s arguments [3] one can prove that if ∈X,YA1 satisfy (2) then =⁢XY⁢YX. Our approach to the above problem is based on the Krichever–Novikov theory of commuting higher rank ordinary differential operators. Let us recall some basic notions and facts related to commuting differential operators. If =Ln∑=j0n⁢vj(x)∂xj, =Lm∑=k0m⁢uk(x)∂xk commute then there is a Burchnall–Chaundy’s polynomial ⁢F(z,w) which vanishes the operators, =⁢F(Ln,Lm)0.

The spectral curve Γ defined by the equation =F0 is irreducible and is completed at infinity with a unique point q. The spectral curve parametrizes common eigenvalues of Ln and Lm, i.e. if =⁢Lnψ⁢zψ,=⁢Lmψ⁢wψ then ∈(z,w)Γ The dimension of the space of common eigenfunctions for generic P=(z,w)∈Γ is called the rank. Commutative rings of ordinary differential operators were classified by Krichever [4], [5]. In the case of rank one eigenfunctions are Baker–Akhiezer functions, found by Krichever. The case of rank >l1 is very complicated. In this case the eigenfunctions can not be found explicitly. Operators of rank two corresponding to elliptic spectral curves were found by Krichever and Novikov [6], operators of fourth order have the form

Math.text: L _ (K * N) = (((partial-differential _ x) ^ 2 + u) ^ 2 + 2 * c _ x * (Weierstrass-p * gamma _ 2 - Weierstrass-p * gamma _ 1) * partial-differential _ x + (c _ x * (Weierstrass-p * gamma _ 2 - Weierstrass-p * gamma _ 1)) _ x) - Weierstrass-p * gamma _ 2 - Weierstrass-p * gamma _ 1

para.p: where =⁢γ1(x)+γ0⁢c(x),=⁢γ2(x)-γ0⁢c(x)

Math.text: u * x = (((- 1 / (4 * (c _ x) ^ 2)) + (1 / 4) * ((c _ (x * x)) ^ 2 / (c _ x) ^ 2) + 2 * Phi * open-interval@(gamma _ 1, gamma _ 2) * c _ x) - c _ (x * x * x) / (2 * c _ x)) + (c _ x) ^ 2 * (Phi _ c * open-interval@(gamma _ 0 + c, gamma _ 0 - c) - Phi ^ 2 * open-interval@(gamma _ 1, gamma _ 2))
Phi * open-interval@(gamma _ 1, gamma _ 2) = (zeta * (gamma _ 2 - gamma _ 1) + zeta * gamma _ 1) - zeta * gamma _ 2

para.p: ⁢ζ(z),⁢℘(z) are the Weierstrass functions, ⁢c(x) is an arbitrary smooth function, γ0 is a constant. The operator L⁢KN commutes with a six order differential operator ~L⁢KN.
Let us formulate our main results.

p.text: For arbitrary integer >m0 and arbitrary spectral curve Γ given by the equation =w2+z3⁢c2z2⁢c1zc0 there are polynomials

Math.text: formulae@(V _ m = alpha _ (m + 2) * x ^ (m + 2) + ldots + alpha _ 0, formulae@([ ] * W _ m = beta _ m * x ^ m + ldots + beta _ 0, formulae@(alpha _ (m + 2) not-equals 0, beta _ m not-equals 0)))

p.text: such that the operator

Math.text: L _ (list@(4, m)) = ((partial-differential _ x) ^ 2 + V _ m * x) ^ 2 + W _ m * x

p.text: commutes with a six order operator L6,m. The spectral curve of L4,m,L6,m coincides with ñ Γ.

para.p: At =m1 we have

Math.text: formulae@(L _ (list@(4, 1)) = ((partial-differential _ x) ^ 2 + alpha _ 3 * x ^ 3 + alpha _ 2 * x ^ 2 + alpha _ 1 * x + alpha _ 0) ^ 2 + 2 * alpha _ 3 * x, alpha _ 3 not-equals 0.)

para.p: At =α31,α1=α2=0 the operators L4,1,L6,1 coincide with the Dixmier operators [1]. The example of Dixmier was the first example of commutative subalgebra in A1. It is an interesting problem how to obtain L4,m,L6,m from L⁢KN,~L⁢KN? At =m1 the answer is given in the Grinevich’s theorem [7]:
Operator L⁢KN corresponding to the curve =w2+⁢4z3⁢g2zg3 has rational coefficients if and only if

Math.text: c * x = ((integral _ (q * x)) ^ infinity)@((d * t) / square-root@(4 * t ^ 3 + g _ 2 * t + g _ 3))

para.p: where ⁢q(x) is a rational function. If =γ00 and =⁢q(x)x, then L⁢KN coincides with L4,1.
Theorem 1.1 allows to prove the following theorem.

p.text: The set of orbits of the group ⁢Aut(A1) in the space of solutions of arbitrary equation

Math.text: formulae@(Y ^ 2 = list@(X ^ 3 + c _ 2 * X ^ 2 + c _ 1 * X + c _ 0, X), formulae@(Y element-of A _ 1, c _ j element-of C))

p.text: is infinite.

para.p: Commuting operators of rank two of order 4 and +⁢4g2 corresponding to hyperelliptic spectral curves of genus g were studied in [8]. With the help of methods of [8] one can construct rank 2 operators at >g1. For example

Math.text: formulae@((L ^ ^sharp) _ 4 = ((partial-differential _ x) ^ 2 + alpha _ 3 * x ^ 3 + alpha _ 2 * x ^ 2 + alpha _ 1 * x + alpha _ 0) ^ 2 + g * (g + 1) * alpha _ 3 * x, alpha _ 3 not-equals 0)

para.p: commutes with an operator L♯+⁢4g2 [8]. Mokhov [9] proved that if one apply elements of ⁢Aut(A1) to L♯4,L♯+⁢4g2 then one can obtains operators of rank =l⁢2k and =l⁢3k, where k is a positive integer. For example if we apply the automorphism =⁢φ(x)∂x,=⁢φ(∂x)-x to L♯4,L♯+⁢4g2 we obtain rank 3 operators. Herewith

Math.text: varphi * (L ^ ^sharp) _ 4 = (alpha _ 3 * (partial-differential _ x) ^ 3 + alpha _ 2 * (partial-differential _ x) ^ 2 + alpha _ 1 * partial-differential _ x + alpha _ 0 + x ^ 2) ^ 2 + g * (g + 1) * alpha _ 3 * partial-differential _ x

para.p: Another important example constructed in [10] is the following. The operator

Math.text: formulae@((L _ 4) ^ natural = ((partial-differential _ x) ^ 2 + alpha _ 1 * hyperbolic-cosine@(x) + alpha _ 0) ^ 2 + alpha _ 1 * g * (g + 1) * hyperbolic-cosine@(x), alpha _ 1 not-equals 0)

para.p: commutes with L♮+⁢4g2. Using L4♮,L♮+⁢4g2 Mokhov constructed examples of operators of arbitrary rank >l1 [11] (we discuss this construction in section 2). Let Γ♮ be a spectral curve of L4♮,L♮+⁢4g2 given by the equation

Math.text: w ^ 2 = z ^ (2 * g + 1) + (c _ (2 * g)) ^ natural * z ^ (2 * g) + dots + (c _ 1) ^ natural * z + (c _ 0) ^ natural

para.p: Coefficients cj♮ can be found with the help of a recurrent formula (see Lemma 1 bellow). Probably for all g the curve Γ♮ is not singular for general set of parameters α0,α1. For small g using Lemma 1 one can check this by direct calculation.

p.text: The set of orbits of the group ⁢Aut(A1) in the space of solutions of the equation

Math.text: formulae@(Y ^ 2 = list@(X ^ (2 * g + 1) + (c _ (2 * g)) ^ natural * X ^ (2 * g) + dots + (c _ 1) ^ natural * X + (c _ 0) ^ natural, X), Y element-of A _ 1)

p.text: is infinite.

para.p: It would be interesting to check the Berest conjecture at >g1 for generic equation (1) having a nonconstant solution in A1.

The group ⁢Aut(A1) acts on the set of rings of commuting differential operators with affine spectral curves considered in Theorems 1.2 and 1.3. One can prove that the space of orbits is also infinite.

Every ring A of commuting ordinary differential operators is isomorphic to a ring of meromorphic functions on spectral curve Γ with a pole in some point ∈qΓ (we consider in this section the case when Γ is nonsingular, i.e. Γ is a Riemann surface). For a meromorphic function ⁢f(P), ∈PΓ with pole in q of order n we have =⁢Lfψ(x,P)⁢f(P)ψ(x,P) where ∈LfA is a differential operator of order ⁢ln, l is the rank of commuting operators, =ψ(ψ1,…,ψl) is a vector Baker–Akhiezer function. Function ψ can be reconstructed from the following spectral data (see [4])

Math.text: set@(Gamma, q, k ^ (- 1), gamma _ 1, dots, gamma _ (l * g), alpha _ 1, dots, alpha _ (l * g), omega _ 1 * x, dots, omega _ (l - 1) * x)

para.p: Hire k-1 is a local parameter near q, g is the genus of Γ, ∈γjΓ, =αj(αj,1,…,αj,-l1) is a vector, ⁢ωj(x) is a smooth function. The set (γ,α) is called the Tyurin parameters. This parameters define a semi-stable holomorphic rank l vector bundle on Γ of degree ⁢lg with holomorphic sections η1,…,ηl. The points γ1,…,γ⁢lg are points of their linear dependence of the sections

Math.text: eta _ l * gamma _ j = ((sum _ (i = 1)) ^ (l - 1))@(alpha _ (list@(j, i)) * eta _ i * gamma _ j)

para.p: The vector-function ψ is defined by the following properties.
1. In the neighbourhood of q it has the form

Math.text: psi * open-interval@(x, P) = ((sum _ (s = 0)) ^ infinity)@(xi _ s * x * k ^ (- s)) * Phi * open-interval@(x, k)

para.p: where =ξ0(1,0,…,0),=⁢ξi(x)(⁢ξi1(x),…,⁢ξil(x)), the matrix Φ satisfies the equation

Math.text: formulae@((d * Phi) / (d * x) = A * Phi, A = Array[[0, 1, 0, dots, 0, 0], [0, 0, 1, dots, 0, 0], [dots, dots, dots, dots, dots, dots], [0, 0, 0, dots, 0, 1], [k + omega _ 1, omega _ 2, omega _ 3, dots, omega _ (l - 1), 0]])

para.p: 2. The components of ψ are meromorphic functions on \Γ{q} with the simple poles γ1,…,γ⁢lg, and

Math.text: formulae@(formulae@(Res _ gamma _ i * psi _ j = alpha _ (list@(i, j)) * Res _ gamma _ i * psi _ l, 1 less= i less= l * g), 1 less= j less= l - 1.)

para.p: The main difficulty to construct operators of rank >l1 is the fact that the Baker–Akhiezer function is not found explicitly. In the recent paper [12] were shown that the class of Baker–Akhiezer functions contains some known special functions.

Let us recall the method of deformation of Tyurin parameters [6]. The main idea of this method is to study the linear differential operator which vanishes the common eigenfunctions. The common eigenfunctions of commuting differential operators of rank l satisfy the linear differential equation of order l

Math.text: psi ^ l * open-interval@(x, P) = chi _ 0 * open-interval@(x, P) * psi * open-interval@(x, P) + dots + chi _ (l - 1) * open-interval@(x, P) * psi ^ (l - 1) * open-interval@(x, P)

para.p: The coefficients χi are rational functions on Γ with the simple poles ⁢P1(x) … ∈⁢P⁢lg(x)Γ, and with the following expansions in the neighbourhood of q

Math.text: formulae@(chi _ 0 * open-interval@(x, P) = k + g _ 0 * x + O * k ^ (- 1), formulae@(chi _ j * open-interval@(x, P) = g _ j * x + O * k ^ (- 1), 0 less j less l - 1))
chi _ (l - 1) * open-interval@(x, P) = O * k ^ (- 1)

para.p: Let -k⁢γi(x) be a local parameter near ⁢Pi(x). Then

Math.text: chi _ j = (c _ (list@(i, j)) * x) / (k - gamma _ i * x) + d _ (list@(i, j)) * x + O * (k - gamma _ i * x)

para.p: Functions ⁢c⁢ij(x),⁢d⁢ij(x) satisfy the following equations (see [4]).

Math.text: c _ (list@(i, l - 1)) * x = - (gamma ^ prime) _ i * x
d _ (list@(i, 0)) * x = (alpha _ (list@(i, 0)) * x * alpha _ (list@(i, l - 2)) * x + alpha _ (list@(i, 0)) * x * d _ (list@(i, l - 1)) * x) - (alpha ^ prime) _ (list@(i, 0)) * x

formulae@(d _ (list@(i, j)) * x = ((alpha _ (list@(i, j)) * x * alpha _ (list@(i, l - 2)) * x - alpha _ (list@(i, j - 1)) * x) + alpha _ (list@(i, j)) * x * d _ (list@(i, l - 1)) * x) - (alpha ^ prime) _ (list@(i, j)) * x, j >= 1)

para.p: where =⁢αi,j(x)⁢ci,j(x)⁢ci,-l1(x), 0≤j≤-l1, 1≤i≤⁢lg To find χi one should solve the equations (4)–(6). Using χi one can find coefficients of the operators. At =g1, =l2 Krichever and Novikov [6] solved these equations and found the operators L⁢KN. Operators of Krichever–Novikov and it applications were studied in [13]–[19] Operators of rank 3 corresponding to elliptic spectral curves were found by Mokhov [20]. In [21]–[24] some examples of operators of rank 2,3 corresponding to spectral curves of genus 2–4 were constructed.
In [8] commuting operators of rank two of order 4 and +⁢4g2 corresponding to hyperelliptic spectral curves were studied

Math.text: formulae@(L _ 4 * psi = z * psi, formulae@(L _ (4 * g + 2) * psi = w * psi, w ^ 2 = F _ g * z = z ^ (2 * g + 1) + c _ (2 * g) * z ^ (2 * g) + dots + c _ 0))

para.p: Common eigenfunctions of L4 and L+⁢4g2 satisfy the second order differential equation

Math.text: formulae@(psi ^ prime2 - chi _ 1 * open-interval@(x, P) * psi ^ prime - chi _ 0 * open-interval@(x, P) * psi = 0, P = open-interval@(z, w) element-of Gamma)

para.p: where ⁢χ0(x,P),⁢χ1(x,P) are rational functions on Γ satisfying equations (4)–(6).
Theorem 2 ([8]) The operator L4 is formally self-adjoint if and only if

Math.text: chi _ 1 * open-interval@(x, P) = chi _ 1 * open-interval@(x, sigma * P)

p.text: where σ is the hyperelliptic involution on Γ.

para.p: Theorem 3 ([8]) If L4 is formally self-adjoint, i.e. =L4+(+∂x2⁢V(x))2⁢W(x) then

Math.text: formulae@(chi _ 0 = ((- (1 / 2) * (Q _ (x * x) / Q)) + w / Q) - V, chi _ 1 = Q _ x / Q)

p.text: where =Q+zg⁢a-g1(x)z-g1…⁢a0(x),⁢a0(x),…,⁢a-g1(x) are some functions. The function Q satisfies the equation

para.p: From Theorem 3 it follows

p.text: Corollary 1
The function Q satisfies the linear equation

Math.text: (((partial-differential _ x) ^ 5)@(Q) + 4 * V * Q _ (x * x * x) + 6 * V _ x * Q _ (x * x) + 2 * ((2 * z - 2 * W) + V _ (x * x)) * Q _ x) - 2 * W _ x * Q = 0.

p.text: Corollary 2
If =g1 then
where F1 defines the spectral curve w2=⁢F1(x)=+z3⁢c2z2⁢c1zc0

para.p: With the help of Theorem 3 many examples of rank 2 operators were recently constructed (see [25]–[27]).

Let us consider commuting operators L4♮,L+⁢4g2♮ [10]. These operators do not commute with operators of odd orders [28], hence these operators are operators of true rank 2. The polynomial Q for L4♮,L+⁢4g2♮ has the form (see [10])

Math.text: Q * open-interval@(x, z) = A _ g * z * (hyperbolic-cosine ^ g)@(x) + dots + A _ 1 * z * hyperbolic-cosine@(x) + A _ 0 * z

para.p: where

Math.text: list@((- 8 * A _ (s + 2) * ((s + 2)factorial / sfactorial) * (2 * s + 3) * alpha _ 1) + 4 * A _ (s + 1) * (s + 1) * (s + 1) ^ 2 * (4 * alpha _ 0 + (s + 1) ^ 2 + 4 * z), 0) less= s less g

para.p: we assume that =As0 at <s0 and >sg, Ag is a constant.
Lemma 1 ([8]) The spectral curve Γ♮ of L4♮,L+⁢4g2♮ is given by the equation

p.text: where ⁢Aj(z) are defined in (10).
Examples:

para.p: 2) =g2, let for simplicity of formulas =α00
The spectral curves defined by the above equations are not singular for the general parameters.
Mokhov [11] found a remarkable change of variable
which reduces the operators L4♮,L+⁢4g2♮ to the operators with polynomial coefficients. In particular, L4♮ in new variable y gets the form

Math.text: formulae@((L _ 4) ^ natural = (((1 - y ^ 2) * (partial-differential _ y) ^ 2 - 3 * y * partial-differential _ y) + a * T _ r * y + b) ^ 2 - a * r ^ 2 * g * (g + 1) * T _ r * y, a not-equals 0)

para.p: b is arbitrary constant, ⁢Tr(y) is the Chebyshev polynomial of degree |r|. Recall that

Math.text: formulae@(T _ 0 * y = 1, formulae@(T _ 1 * y = y, formulae@(T _ r * y = 2 * y * T _ (r - 1) * y - T _ (r - 2) * y, T _ (- r) * y = T _ r * y)))

para.p: Chebyshev polynomials are commuting polynomials, i.e.

Math.text: T _ n * T _ m * y = T _ m * T _ n * y = T _ (n + m) * y

para.p: If one applies the automorphism

Math.text: formulae@(varphi * y = - partial-differential _ y, formulae@(varphi * partial-differential _ y = y, varphi element-of A * u * t * A _ 1))

para.p: to the operators L4♮,L+⁢4g2♮ written in y variable, then one gets operators of orders ⁢2r,⁢(+⁢2g1)r of rank r [11] and

Math.text: varphi * (L _ 4) ^ natural = ((a * T _ r * partial-differential _ y - y ^ 2 * (partial-differential _ y) ^ 2 - 3 * y * partial-differential _ y) + y ^ 2 + b) ^ 2 - a * r * g * (g + 1) * T _ r * partial-differential _ y

para.p: Let us rewrite (9) in the form
Note that from (11) it follows
Further we assume that V,W are polynomials

Math.text: formulae@(V = alpha _ n * x ^ n + ldots + alpha _ 0, formulae@([ ] * W = beta _ m * x ^ m + ldots + beta _ 0, formulae@(alpha _ n not-equals 0, beta _ m not-equals 0.)))

para.p: Equation (11) is equivalent to the system of equations: equation (12) and the equation on free terms of (11) which is
Let us prove the following important proposition.

p.text: For any >m0 there exists a solution of the equation (11) of the form (13), where =n+m2.

para.p: Equation (12) is equivalent to a system of +⁢2m1 equations in +⁢2m4 variables αi,βj. Note that all equations have degree 2 and the set of their solutions consists of points in C+⁢2m4 (with coordinates αi,βj) which lie in the intersection of +⁢2m1 quadrics defined by these equations. By [29, Ch.1,Th.7.2] the intersection X of these quadrics in ℙ+⁢2m4 (with homogeneous coordinates αi,βj,u) is non-empty and each its irreducible component has dimension greater or equal to 3. By the same reason the intersection of X with the hyperplane Z={u=0} at infinity is non-empty and each its irreducible component has dimension greater or equal to 2.

To prove the proposition it is sufficient to prove that for any fixed >m0 there is a two-dimensional irreducible component of ∩XZ. From this fact we can conclude that affine part of the intersection of quadrics is non-empty.
The homogeneous parts of our equations in ℙ+⁢2m4 not depending on u can be easily written: these are exactly the coefficients at xi of the sum
Let us introduce the following notations:
Then the intersection ∩XZ is given by the equations

Math.text: formulae@((4 * c _ i + 2 * b _ i) - 3 * d _ i = 0, [ ] * i = list@(0, ldots, 2 * m))

para.p: Note that the coefficients bi,ci,di can be written in the following form:

Math.text: formulae@(d _ i = ((sum _ (k = 0)) ^ i)@(beta _ (i - k) * beta _ k), formulae@([ ] * b _ i = ((sum _ (k = 0)) ^ i)@(B _ (list@(k, i)) * alpha _ ((i - k) + 1) * beta _ (k + 1)), [ ] * c _ i = ((sum _ (k = 0)) ^ i)@(C _ (list@(k, i)) * alpha _ (i - k) * beta _ (k + 2))))

para.p: where =Bk,i⁢(+k1)(+-ik1),=Ck,i⁢(+k1)(+k2) are positive integers, and we set ≡αj0 if >jn, ≡βj0 if >jm.
The next observation is: equations (16), (17) always have a solution of the form

for any >m0. Indeed, if α0=…=α-n1=β0=…=β-m1=0, then only ⁢2m-th equation from (16) remains to be non-trivial, and this equation becomes a quadratic homogeneous equation linear in αn and quadratic in βm:

Math.text: (2 * B _ (list@(m - 1, 2 * m)) + 4 * C _ (list@(m - 2, 2 * m))) * alpha _ n * beta _ m - 3 * (beta _ m) ^ 2 = 0.

para.p: Thus, we can set =βm1 where from =αn/3(+⁢2B-m1,⁢2m⁢4C-m2,⁢2m).
Let us prove that for any fixed >m0 any irreducible component of ∩XZ containing P has dimension 2.
If =m1 then there are only 3 equations in (16)

Math.text: (4 * C _ (list@(0, 0)) * alpha _ 0 * beta _ 2 + 2 * B _ (list@(0, 0)) * alpha _ 1 * beta _ 2) - 3 * (beta _ 0) ^ 2 = 0

(4 * (C _ (list@(0, 1)) * alpha _ 1 * beta _ 2 + C _ (list@(1, 2)) * alpha _ 0 * beta _ 3) + 2 * (B _ (list@(0, 1)) * alpha _ 2 * beta _ 1 + B _ (list@(1, 1)) * alpha _ 1 * beta _ 2)) - 6 * beta _ 0 * beta _ 1 = 0

(4 * (C _ (list@(0, 2)) * alpha _ 2 * beta _ 2 + C _ (list@(1, 2)) * alpha _ 1 * beta _ 3 + C _ (list@(2, 2)) * alpha _ 0 * beta _ 4) + 2 * (B _ (list@(0, 2)) * alpha _ 3 * beta _ 1 + B _ (list@(1, 2)) * alpha _ 2 * beta _ 2 + B _ (list@(2, 2)) * alpha _ 1 * beta _ 3)) - 3 * (2 * beta _ 0 * beta _ 2 + (beta _ 1) ^ 2) = 0

para.p: and their Jacobi matrix at P has the following form:

where the first columns denote derivations with respect to α0,…,α3, and the last two columns denote derivations with respect to β0,β1. The rank of the matrix is 3, so, these equations define a smooth variety in the neighbourhood of the point P of dimension two.

For generic m the point P might not be regular. Nevertheless, any irreducible component containing P has a dense subset of smooth points. At any such point Q the Jacobi matrix J can be written in the following form. It can be divided in two blocks: one consists of +m1 columns (derivations of equations with respect to β0,…,βm), and another one consists of +n1 columns (derivations of equations with respect to αn,…,α0). We shall describe only essential columns for us.
The columns of the first block are (to save the space we shall write them as rows):

Math.text: [2-nd column: ] * vector@(j _ (list@(0, 0)) * alpha _ 1, j _ (list@(0, 1)) * alpha _ 2 - 6 * beta _ 0, j _ (list@(0, 2)) * alpha _ 3 - 6 * beta _ 1, ldots, j _ (list@(0, n - 1)) * alpha _ n - 6 * beta _ m, 0, ldots, 0)
[3-d column: ] * vector@(j _ (list@(1, 0)) * alpha _ 0, j _ (list@(1, 1)) * alpha _ 1, j _ (list@(1, 2)) * alpha _ 2 - 6 * beta _ 0, ldots, j _ (list@(1, n)) * alpha _ n - 6 * beta _ m, 0, ldots, 0)

[4-th column: ] * vector@(0, j _ (list@(2, 1)) * alpha _ 0, j _ (list@(2, 2)) * alpha _ 1, j _ (list@(2, 3)) * alpha _ 2 - 6 * beta _ 0, ldots, j _ (list@(2, n + 1)) * alpha _ n - 6 * beta _ m, 0, ldots, 0)

[5-th column: ] * vector@(0, 0, j _ (list@(3, 2)) * alpha _ 0, j _ (list@(3, 3)) * alpha _ 1, j _ (list@(3, 4)) * alpha _ 2 - 6 * beta _ 0, ldots, j _ (list@(3, n + 2)) * alpha _ n - 6 * beta _ m, 0, ldots, 0)
list@(ldots, ldots, ldots)

[(m+1)-th column: ] * vector@(0, ldots, 0, j _ (list@(m - 1, m - 2)) * alpha _ 0, j _ (list@(m - 1, m - 1)) * alpha _ 1, j _ (list@(m - 1, m)) * alpha _ 2 - 6 * beta _ 0, ldots, j _ (list@(m - 1, 2 * m)) * alpha _ n - 6 * beta _ m)

para.p: the columns of the second block are:

Math.text: [1-st column: ] * vector@(0, ldots, 0, j _ (list@(0, m + 1)) * beta _ 1, j _ (list@(1, m + 2)) * beta _ 2, ldots, j _ (list@(m - 1, 2 * m)) * beta _ m)
[2-nd column: ] * vector@(0, ldots, 0, j _ (list@(0, m)) * beta _ 1, j _ (list@(1, m + 1)) * beta _ 2, ldots, j _ (list@(m - 1, 2 * m - 1)) * beta _ m, 0)
[3-d column: ] * vector@(0, ldots, 0, j _ (list@(0, m - 1)) * beta _ 1, j _ (list@(1, m)) * beta _ 2, ldots, j _ (list@(m - 1, 2 * m - 2)) * beta _ m, 0, 0)
list@(ldots, ldots, ldots)
[n-th column: ] * vector@(j _ (list@(0, 0)) * beta _ 1, j _ (list@(1, 1)) * beta _ 2, ldots, j _ (list@(m - 1, m - 1)) * beta _ m, 0, ldots, 0)
[(n+1)-th column: ] * vector@(j _ (list@(1, 0)) * beta _ 2, ldots, j _ (list@(m - 1, m - 2)) * beta _ m, 0, ldots, 0)

para.p: where the numbers jk,l are defined as

Math.text: j _ (list@(k, l)) = 2 * B _ (list@(k, l)) + 4 * C _ (list@(k - 1, l))

para.p: where we assume =Bk,l0 if >kl and =Ck,l0 if <k0.

Without loss of generality we can assume that the point Q belongs to a sufficiently small neighbourhood of the point P (in the complex topology), such that, for fixed numbers jk,l, the modules of all terms of the matrix J, except the terms containing =βm1 and αn, are comparable with some 0<ϵ≪1 (i.e. they are <ϵ but >ϵ2). We call such terms comparable with ϵ.

We have the following possibilities now. If there is a smooth point Q such that its coordinate ≠α00 or ≠α10, then the rank of the matrix J is +⁢2m1, i.e. the dimension of the component is two. Indeed, we can first apply the Gauss elimination algorithm to kill all terms of the right part of the matrix lying over terms containing βm. We can choose ϵ small enough such that the terms of the left part of J will change, but the top non-zero elements of the first -m2 rows will remain non-zero and comparable with ϵ, and all elements over them will be comparable with ϵ2. Applying again the Gauss elimination algorithm we can kill all elements in the columns except these top non-zero elements, thus obtaining +⁢2m1 linearly independent rows in the matrix J.

Note that the case =α00, ≠α10 (i.e. =α00 for all smooth points) is in fact impossible: in this case the whole component belongs to the hyperplane =α00. But then the dimension of the component must be 1, a contradiction.

Now we claim that there exists a smooth point such that ≠α00 or ≠α10. Indeed, if there are no such smooth points, then the whole component belongs to the intersection of hyperplanes α0=α1=0 (cf. [29, Ch.1,ex.1.6]). Note that in this case from 0-th equation in (16) it follows =β00, and from the 1-st equation it follows =⁢α2β10.

Let’s show first that α2=β1=0. If there is a smooth point in the component with ≠α20, then the Jacobi matrix of our system restricted to the ⁢2m-dimensional intersection of hyperplanes α0=α1=β0=0 reduces to the following matrix.
The columns of the first block are (to save the space we will again write them as rows):

Math.text: [1-st column: ] * vector@(j _ (list@(0, 1)) * alpha _ 2, j _ (list@(0, 2)) * alpha _ 3 - 6 * beta _ 1, ldots, j _ (list@(0, n - 1)) * alpha _ n - 6 * beta _ m, 0, ldots, 0)
[2-nd column: ] * vector@(0, j _ (list@(1, 2)) * alpha _ 2, j _ (list@(1, 3)) * alpha _ 3 - 6 * beta _ 1, ldots, j _ (list@(1, n)) * alpha _ n - 6 * beta _ m, 0, ldots, 0)
[3-d column: ] * vector@(0, 0, j _ (list@(2, 3)) * alpha _ 2, ldots, j _ (list@(2, n + 1)) * alpha _ n - 6 * beta _ m, 0, ldots, 0)
list@(ldots, ldots, ldots * ldots)
[m-th column: ] * vector@(0, ldots, 0, j _ (list@(m - 1, m)) * alpha _ 2, ldots, j _ (list@(m - 1, 2 * m)) * alpha _ n - 6 * beta _ m)

para.p: the columns of the second block are:

Math.text: [1-st column: ] * vector@(0, ldots, 0, j _ (list@(0, m + 1)) * beta _ 1, j _ (list@(1, m + 2)) * beta _ 2, ldots, j _ (list@(m - 1, 2 * m)) * beta _ m)
[2-nd column: ] * vector@(0, ldots, 0, j _ (list@(0, m)) * beta _ 1, j _ (list@(1, m + 1)) * beta _ 2, ldots, j _ (list@(m - 1, 2 * m - 1)) * beta _ m, 0)
[3-d column: ] * vector@(0, ldots, 0, j _ (list@(0, m - 1)) * beta _ 1, j _ (list@(1, m)) * beta _ 2, ldots, j _ (list@(m - 1, 2 * m - 2)) * beta _ m, 0, 0)
list@(ldots, ldots, ldots)
[(n-1)-th column: ] * vector@(j _ (list@(0, 1)) * beta _ 1, ldots, j _ (list@(m - 1, m)) * beta _ m, 0, ldots, 0)

para.p: where the m columns of the first block denote derivations with respect to β1,…,βm, and the -n1 columns of the second block denote derivations with respect to αn,…,α2.

Since β1 must be equal to zero, we can apply the same arguments as above and obtain that the rank of this matrix is ⁢2m. But this is impossible, because the dimension of the component is not less than two.

If the whole component belongs to the intersection Y={α0=α1=α2=β0=0}, but there are smooth points with ≠β10, then the 2-th equation in (16) reduces to =-⁢2B0,2α3β1⁢3β120, where from we see that α3=/⁢3β1(⁢2B0,2)≠0. In this case analogously to the previous case the matrix J reduces to the following matrix.
The columns of the first block are:

Math.text: [1-st column: ] * vector@(j _ (list@(0, 2)) * alpha _ 3 - 6 * beta _ 1, ldots, j _ (list@(0, n - 1)) * alpha _ n - 6 * beta _ m, 0, ldots, 0)
[2-nd column: ] * vector@(0, j _ (list@(1, 3)) * alpha _ 3 - 6 * beta _ 1, ldots, j _ (list@(1, n)) * alpha _ n - 6 * beta _ m, 0, ldots, 0)
list@(ldots, ldots, ldots * ldots)
[m-th column: ] * vector@(0, ldots, 0, j _ (list@(m - 1, m + 1)) * alpha _ 3 - 6 * beta _ 1, ldots, j _ (list@(m - 1, 2 * m)) * alpha _ n - 6 * beta _ m)

para.p: the columns of the second block are:

Math.text: [1-st column: ] * vector@(0, ldots, 0, j _ (list@(0, m + 1)) * beta _ 1, j _ (list@(1, m + 2)) * beta _ 2, ldots, j _ (list@(m - 1, 2 * m)) * beta _ m)
[2-nd column: ] * vector@(0, ldots, 0, j _ (list@(0, m)) * beta _ 1, j _ (list@(1, m + 1)) * beta _ 2, ldots, j _ (list@(m - 1, 2 * m - 1)) * beta _ m, 0)
[3-d column: ] * vector@(0, ldots, 0, j _ (list@(0, m - 1)) * beta _ 1, j _ (list@(1, m)) * beta _ 2, ldots, j _ (list@(m - 1, 2 * m - 2)) * beta _ m, 0, 0)
list@(ldots, ldots, ldots)
[(n-2)-th column: ] * vector@(j _ (list@(0, 2)) * beta _ 1, ldots, j _ (list@(m - 1, m + 1)) * beta _ m, 0, ldots, 0)

para.p: where the m columns of the first block denote derivations with respect to β1,…,βm, and the -n1 columns of the second block denote derivations with respect to αn,…,α3.

Now the situation differs from the first main case. If we apply the Gauss elimination algorithm to kill all terms of the right part of the matrix lying over terms containing βm, we can destroy the top non-zero terms. So, we must control the changes of these terms modulo ϵ2. Fortunately, it is not difficult: the term -⁢j-m1k,-n1kα3⁢6β1, where 0≤k≤-m1, will be changed to the term

Math.text: j _ (list@(m - 1 - k, n - 1 - k)) * alpha _ 3 - 6 * beta _ 1 - (j _ (list@(0, (m + 1) - k)) / j _ (list@(m - 1, 2 * m - k))) * (j _ (list@(m - 1 - k, 2 * m - k)) * alpha _ n - 6) * beta _ 1 = absent

para.p: As it can be easily checked, the numerator can be equal to zero only for >k-m1. Thus, the rank of J is equal to =-⁢2m1dimY, a contradiction.

Now we can use the induction: suppose we have proved that the whole component belongs to the intersection Y={α0=…=α-l1=0=β0=…=β-l2}. Then the -⁢2(-l1)1-th equation in (16) implies =⁢αlβ-l10. If there is a smooth point with ≠αl0, then we can apply the arguments from the first main case to show that the matrix J has the maximal rank equal to the dimension of Y, a contradiction. If there is a smooth point with ≠β-l10, then from ⁢2(-l1)-th equation we get
and, analogously to the case =α20, ≠β10, we can control the changes of the top non-zero terms (-⁢j-m1k,+-m1klα+l1⁢6β-l1), ≤lm. They will be changed to the terms

Math.text: j _ (list@(m - 1 - k, (m - 1 - k) + l)) * alpha _ (l + 1) - 6 * beta _ (l - 1) - (j _ (list@(l - 2, (m - 1 - k) + l)) / j _ (list@(m - 1, 2 * m - k))) * (j _ (list@(m - 1 - k, 2 * m - k)) * alpha _ n - 6) * beta _ (l - 1) = absent

para.p: The last expression is equal to zero only for k=+-2⁢2lm>m or

But the last expression can not be integer. Indeed, the great common divisor of m and (+-+-1⁢2ll2m⁢lmm2) must divide also the numerator, i.e. the doubled fraction must be integer. On the other hand, it is clear that the fraction is positive and less than one. It also easy to check that it can not be equal to /12.

At the end we obtain that the whole component belongs to the intersection Y={α0=…=αm=0=β0=…=β-m1} with =dimY2. Then from (-⁢2m1)-th equation we obtain ≡α+m10, i.e. the component lies in Y∩{α+m1=0}, whose dimension is one, a contradiction. ∎

Let us prove Theorem 1.1 The intersection X′ (in ℙ+⁢2m4) of X from proposition 3.1 and the cubic defined by (14) is again non-empty, and each its irreducible component has dimension greater or equal to 2; the intersection ∩X′Z with Z is non-empty and each its irreducible component has dimension greater or equal to 1. The homogeneous part of (14) not depending on u is

Math.text: alpha _ 0 * (beta _ 1) ^ 2 + (beta _ 0) ^ 3 / 2.

para.p: It also has a solution of the form P from proposition 3.1.
To prove Theorem 1.1 it is sufficient to prove that for any fixed >m0 any irreducible component of ∩X′Z containing P has dimension 1.

Note that if ≠α00, then either β1 or β0 is not equal to 0. Indeed, if β0=β1=0, then from 0-th equation it follows that =β20, from 1-st equation it follows that =β30 and, by iteration, =βm0, a contradiction.

Let Q be a smooth point on some irreducible component of ∩X′Z as in the proof of proposition 3.1. Consider the new Jacobi matrix with the first row consisting of partial derivatives of the equation (18):

Math.text: vector@(3 * (beta _ 0) ^ 2, 2 * alpha _ 0 * beta _ 1, 0, ldots, 0, (beta _ 1) ^ 2)

para.p: If ≠α00, then it’s easy to see that this row and all other rows of the old matrix J are linearly independent, i.e. the dimension of the component is one.

If =α00, we can literally repeat the arguments from the proof of proposition 3.1. Indeed, as we have already seen, in this case even an irreducible component of ∩XZ would be of dimension less or equal to 1. Theorem 1.1 is proved.
According to Theorem 1.1 an arbitrary equation

Math.text: formulae@(Y ^ 2 = list@(X ^ 3 + c _ 2 * X ^ 2 + c _ 1 * X + c _ 0, X), Y element-of A _ 1)

para.p: has infinitely many solutions of the form =L4,m+(+∂x2⁢Vm(x))2⁢Wm(x),L6,m and the equation

Math.text: formulae@(Y ^ 2 = list@(X ^ (2 * g + 1) + (c _ (2 * g)) ^ natural * X ^ (2 * g) + dots + (c _ 1) ^ natural * X + (c _ 0) ^ natural, X), Y element-of A _ 1)

para.p: also has infinitely many solutions of the form ⁢φ♮(L♮4),⁢φ♮(L♮+⁢4g2) where

Math.text: L * r = varphi ^ natural * (L ^ natural) _ 4 = (((1 - y ^ 2) * (partial-differential _ y) ^ 2 - 3 * y * partial-differential _ y) + a * T _ r * y + b) ^ 2 - a * r ^ 2 * g * (g + 1) * T _ r * y

para.p: ⁢Tr(y) is the Chebyshev polynomial of degree |r| (see section 2). To prove Theorem 1.2 and Theorem 1.3 it is enough to prove that at >r10 and ≠rr1

Math.text: formulae@(varphi * L _ (list@(4, r)) not-equals L _ (list@(4, r _ 1)), varphi * L * r not-equals L * r _ 1)

para.p: for arbitrary ∈φ⁢Aut(A1). This facts follow from the following lemma.

p.text: Consider a family of operators of order four with polynomial coefficients

Math.text: formulae@(L * r = (a * x * (partial-differential _ x) ^ 2 + b * x * partial-differential _ x + c _ r * x) ^ 2 + d _ r * x, [ ] * r element-of [ℕ])

p.text: where ⁢a(x),⁢b(x) are polynomials of fixed degree such that

Math.text: formulae@(deg * a * x > deg * b * x, formulae@(deg * c _ r * x = r, r >= deg * d _ r * x))

p.text: If >r+⁢dega(x)8, then

Math.text: varphi * L * r not-equals L * r _ 1

p.text: at ≠rr1 for arbitrary ∈φ⁢Aut(A1).

para.p: Here we assume that =⁢degb(x)-∞ if =⁢b(x)0.
Let us assume that there is ∈φ⁢Aut(A1) such that at >r+⁢dega(x)8 we have =⁢φ(⁢L(r))⁢L(r1) for some ≠rr1. Let

Math.text: formulae@(varphi * x = q _ n * x * (partial-differential _ x) ^ n + dots + q _ 0 * x, varphi * partial-differential _ x = p _ m * x * (partial-differential _ x) ^ m + dots + p _ 0 * x)

para.p: where qj,ps are some polynomials. First consider the case =n0. If =n0, then =m1 otherwise the operator ⁢φ(⁢L(r)) has order greater than four. Further,

Math.text: varphi * (a * x * (partial-differential _ x) ^ 2 + b * x * partial-differential _ x) = a * q _ 0 * x * (p _ 1 * x * partial-differential _ x + p _ 0 * x) ^ 2 + b * q _ 0 * x * (p _ 1 * x * partial-differential _ x + p _ 0 * x) = absent
a * q _ 0 * x * (p _ 1) ^ 2 * x * (partial-differential _ x) ^ 2 + limit-from@(a * q _ 0 * x * (p _ 1 * x * (p _ 1) ^ prime * x + p _ 0 * x + b * q _ 0 * x * p _ 1 * x) * partial-differential _ x, +)

para.p: From our assumption it follows that

Math.text: formulae@(a * q _ 0 * x * (p _ 1) ^ 2 * x = a * x, a * q _ 0 * x * (p _ 1 * x * (p _ 1) ^ prime * x + p _ 0 * x) + b * q _ 0 * x * p _ 1 * x = b * x)

para.p: Hence from the first identity we get that ⁢p1(x) is a constant and ⁢q0(x) is a linear function. From the second identity we get that ⁢p0(x) is a constant, otherwise the degree of the left hand side is greater than the degree of the right hand side. Thus

Math.text: formulae@(varphi * x = s _ 1 * x + s _ 2, formulae@(varphi * partial-differential _ x = s _ 3 * partial-differential _ x + s _ 4, s _ j element-of C))

para.p: From this we obtain ≠⁢φ(⁢L(r))⁢L(r1)
Let us consider the general case ≠n0. We have the following identities for orders of differential operators

Math.text: formulae@(ord * varphi * a * x * (partial-differential _ x) ^ 2 = n * deg * a * x + 2 * m, formulae@(ord * varphi * b * x * partial-differential _ x = n * deg * b * x + m, ord * varphi * c _ r * x = r * n))

para.p: Let us note that

Math.text: ord * varphi * a * x * (partial-differential _ x) ^ 2 = ord * varphi * c _ r * x

para.p: for otherwise, since >⁢ordφ(⁢a(x)∂x2)⁢ordφ(⁢b(x)∂x) we have

Math.text: ord * varphi * (a * x * (partial-differential _ x) ^ 2 + b * x * partial-differential _ x + c _ r * x) = ord * varphi * (a * x * (partial-differential _ x) ^ 2 + c _ r * x) = maximum@(r * n, n * degree@(a) * x + 2 * m) >= r

para.p: and therefore ⁢ordφ(⁢L(r))≥⁢2r>4 a contradiction. Thus,

Math.text: n * deg * a * x + 2 * m = r * n

para.p: By direct calculations one can check that

Math.text: ad * (- x) ^ 3 * L * r = closed-interval@(closed-interval@(closed-interval@(L * r, x), x), x) = 24 * a ^ 2 * x * partial-differential _ x + 12 * a * x * b * x + 12 * a * x * a ^ prime * x

para.p: hence

Math.text: ord * varphi * ad * (- x) ^ 3 * L * r = 2 * n * deg * a * x + m

para.p: On the other hand,

Math.text: varphi * ad * (- x) ^ 3 * L * r = ad * (- varphi * x) ^ 3 * varphi * L * r

para.p: We have

Math.text: formulae@(ord * closed-interval@(varphi * L * r, varphi * x) less= n + 3, ord * closed-interval@(closed-interval@(varphi * L * r, varphi * x), varphi * x) less= 2 * n + 2)
ord * closed-interval@(closed-interval@(closed-interval@(varphi * L * r, varphi * x), varphi * x), varphi * x) less= 3 * n + 1.

para.p: Thus, using (19) and our assumption >r+⁢dega(x)8, we get

Math.text: 3 * n + 1 >= ord * delimited-[]@(ad * (- varphi * x) ^ 3 * varphi * L * r) = 2 * n * deg * a * x + m = (n * (r + 3 * d * e * g * a * x)) / 2 > (n / 2) * (8 + 4 * d * e * g * a * x) = absent
4 * n + 2 * n * deg * a * x

para.p: We get a contradiction. ∎
Hence Theorems 1.2 and 1.3 are proved.

Acknowledgements The authors started to discuss the problems considered in this paper on the conference ”Around Sato’s Theory on Soliton Equations” in Tsuda College. They are grateful to this institution for the kind hospitality and to Atsushi Nakayashiki for the invitation.

para.p: A.E. Mironov, Sobolev Institute of Mathematics and Novosibirsk State University, Russia; e-mail: mironov@math.nsc.ru
